source_sentence: 亂風吹地塵沙瓦礫填塞王路。
translation: A turbulent wind blows the dust and dirt on the ground, and rubble fills the king's path.
He pulls out a tree, breaks down its branches, and drops the flowers and fruits.

source_sentence: 掣電霹靂孔雀皆鳴天諸災雹。
translation: The lightning bolts, thunderbolts, and peacocks all sound heavenly hailstorms.

source_sentence: 雖有此變其人都不覺聞。
translation: Even though there's this transformation, people don't even perceive it.
He lifted the bowl full of oil and went to another country.
They won't fall into a single lump.

source_sentence: 王乃歡喜立為大臣(出修行歡喜經)。
translation: The king then rejoiced and appointed him as his minister (from the Sutra of the Joyfulness of Cultivation).

source_sentence: 驢首王食雪山藥草得作人頭十三
translation: The Donkey-Headed King Who Eats the Healing Herbs of the Snowy Mountains Can Be made into a Human Head! 13.
In the past, there was a king.
The human body is the head of a donkey.
The Buddha said to the king of the kingdom.
There's medicine in the snowy mountains.
It's called superior taste.
The king went to eat it, and then he could restore his human head.
The king went to the snowy mountains to search for a doctor to treat it.
So he didn't change his head.
The king returned and said to the Buddha.
Why is it a false statement?
The Buddha said to the king.
Don't let the herbs and plants simply return to your own human head.
The king returned to the mountain.
Those who are born in the mountains will all remove their illnesses themselves.
It's no longer a simple selection.

source_sentence: 噉一口草即復人頭(出雜譬喻經)。
translation: When he eats a mouthful of grass, he'll return to the human head (from the Sutra of Miscellaneous Metaphors).
A Forest of Pearls from the Dharma Garden, Volume I The King Aśoka kills and sleeps.
In the past, there was a king.
Day and night, he didn't sleep.
If the side is straight, he'll be killed if he sleeps.
Four hundred and ninety-nine people were killed before and after.
There's an elderly man who should go straight in.
His family cried in tears and sent him off.
He had asked a question for a little over a year.
Why are they weeping and wailing?
I'll answer them in terms of reality.
You can hire me.
I can stand in for you.
The elder was greatly delighted.
He gave him a thousand taels of gold and sent it to enter directly.
The king said.
How can you enter?
He said, On my behalf, the elder's son is straight.
The king said.
You should be careful not to sleep. I will kill you.
The boy then fell asleep.
The king wanted to kill him.
He said, Why are you sleeping?
He said, Don't sleep; I'm thinking about things.
The king said.
What's to be thought of?
He said, Make a one-ounce vessel and accept two-ounce things.
He filled it with one sheng of sand and another sheng of water.
The king tested him for the truth.
Again, he fell asleep and rolled over to the ground.
The king then wanted to kill him again.
He said, It's a matter of contemplation.
He asked what he thought.

source_sentence: 曰作一尺坑還持土填不滿八寸。
translation: He said, Make a one-foot pit and return it with dirt that's less than eight inches long.
The king again sent someone to make it for you to examine.
Again, he fell asleep and lay on the ground.
The king then wanted to kill him again.
He asked, Why are you sleeping again?
He said, I'm thinking about things.
The king forgives my sins, and I will explain them.
The king said, I'll explain it.
The young man said.
The king is exactly like a ghost.
After he finished speaking, he departed.
The king thought.
Why would this person call me a ghost?
He then asked his mother.
The mother said.
You're really a ghost.
When I harbored it in your mind, I dreamt of seeing a ghost at night.
You'll have your ears when you meet with me.
The king then sat cross-legged.
It's good to repent of not killing people.
He then studied the Way.
At the time, the king was me.

source_sentence: 四百九十九人者今五百上首弟子是。
translation: The four hundred and ninety-nine disciples are now the five hundred supreme disciples.
A young man who perceives the self and attacks me.

source_sentence: 文殊師利是(出譬喻經第五卷)。
translation: This is Mañjuśrī (from the fifth volume of the Parable Sutra).
Sutra and Vinaya: Distinct Forms, Volume 29
